body:
Digital marketing can seem like an overwhelming mix of platforms, measurement tools and techniques.


That is why businesses need to be crystal clear about what they want to achieve with their marketing before they spend any time or money. 


Let's take a look at:

  • What is marketing?
  • What needs to be included in your marketing plan
  • How your marketing needs to change as your business grows
title: Text Title

body:
Marketing is often defined as everything a business does to meet the changing needs and wants of customers, and do it  better than its competitors, while making a profit. 


Hermann Hauser, tech entrepreneur, shares his thoughts on the role of marketing for a business.
title: What is marketing?

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222516068" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

displayTitle: What does marketing bring to a business?
body: Here are some of the different ways of thinking about the function of marketing in a business.

_items.backText:
A customer-centric philosophy

Marketing generates golden insights for companies, identifying what customers really want. 

For example, a digital advertising campaign made up of 5 different advertisements relating to 5 types of shoes. 

You might see that kitten heels generated 50% more clicks than other shoes. This might inform how you stock your shop, how you arrange your website and how you run promotions.

Insights into what customers really want

Marketing gives key insights into what customers really want.

If you ran a series of digital adverts offering slightly different products to see which products get the most engagement, you can tell what customers will want even before you have to make the products. 

By testing different messages in your campaigns, you can work out what is really important to customers and build products around their needs and desires.

Customers buying your product

The most common benefit of marketing is that it converts potential customers into loyal paying customers. This is key to any business.
The old saying 'build it and they will come' is unfortunately very uncommon - it takes planning, time and skill to make your audience aware that you exist, as well as to convince customers that you are the best offer on the market.

title: What does marketing bring to a business?

body:
Marketing is a socio-economic process. Buyers and sellers exchange goods and services between each other with both reaping the benefits from the transaction and the products exchanged.


Once you have decided who is your target market and what your marketing is going to say, think about how you can use the 4Ps - Product, price, place, and promotion can influence your customers and win them over.
title: The 4Ps of marketing

body: A good marketing plan should answer the following questions.
displayTitle: What should be in your marketing plan?

_items.title: What are you trying to achieve with your marketing?
_items.body:
Try to make them:

Specific, Measurable, Actionable, Realistic and Timelined 


For example, MumsDeals will target urban design conscious mothers with children under 5, with a mix of online and offline advertising over 6 months to highlight the app and its capabilities. Initial sales estimates from these marketing avenues are estimated at around 10,000 units.


Besides sales, other objectives could be: 


To improve product awareness 


For example, MumsDeals aims to become one of the top three brands in the industry as perceived by consumers.


To increase market share 


For example, MumsDeals aims to increase market share by 2% by acquiring 10,000 new customers in the next 12 months.


To differentiate your product 


For example, to clearly establish three key differences between your product compared to your main competitor. This would be measured by surveying potential customers regularly throughout the campaign. 


To promote your solution 


For example, to get at least six endorsements from leading bloggers or newspapers by sending free samples of our work.


To get your first customers  


For example, sell out of the product within 100 days of our launch.

_items.title: Who are your potential customers and how could you group them according to their needs?What is your market and how you can group customers?
_items.body:
This is called customer segmentation. 


An example of a customer segment might be:


Fashionable professional men aged 29 to 45 living in Cambridgeshire.

_items.title: Which groups will you try to reach first?
_items.body: This section will outline which segments you have chosen to target first.

_items.title: How does your company offer more than your competitors?
_items.body:
This is called Positioning.


Show how your 4Ps - Product, Price, Place (where you sell), Promotion are different and better than your competitors.
How you will reach your customers to communicate your key messages.
_items.title: How will you communicate this to customers?

_items.body: How many items you need to sell to break even, and how much you think you will need to spend on marketing to achieve that.
_items.title: How much will you spend on marketing?
Testing and evaluation
_items.body:
How you will monitor if your marketing is working so you can keep tweaking it until it does. 


By treating your marketing activities as a series of tests, you will gain valuable insights to use across the business and find out how to persuade your customers quicker.

title: What should be in your marketing plan?

body:
Consider the smartphone market as an example of a product that has grown over time.


There are four distinct phases of growth between the time the first product is launched and the time it becomes a thing of the past. These phases are: 

  • Introduction
  • Growth
  • Maturity
  • Decline


It is useful to understand how mature your market is, as this will dictate who you should try to reach first and who your competitors are. 


For example, if you are a entering a new market, don't be disheartened if you don't gain traction immediately.

Similarly, if you are entering a mature, strong market, don't be complacent.
displayTitle: Marketing plans change as you grow
title: Marketing plans change as you grow

body:
Emmanuel Carraud at MagicAppFinder shares his experiences of running the marketing strategy for his startup.


MagicAppFinder is an app that sends customers recommendations for paid-for apps which they may like. They then have the opportunity to buy them at a bulk discount.
displayTitle: Founder stories: Our marketing changed as our product grew
title: Founder stories: Our marketing changed as our product grew

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222516190" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body: Which two options can help you market your business?

_items.text: By generating insights about customers that will help the company to better serve your customers
By getting prospective customers to find out about your product and want to buy it
By making sure that everyone knows about your products

title: What is marketing?

body:
There are 3 things below that should be in your marketing plan.


Which is the odd one out?
displayTitle: What should go into my marketing plan?

_feedback.correct:
Well done! 

Brand assets like logo, tagline and fonts don't need to be included in the marketing plan.

_items.text: Who are your customers?
How do your customers shop?
Who are your competitors and how you are offering more?
Samples of your fonts and variations of your logo

title: What should go into my marketing plan?

body: Which phases of a product's life cycle are described in the statements below?

_items.text: Your company is trying to reach the first innovative people to believe in your new product
Your company is trying to make a product become the norm in a market
Your company is fighting to stay ahead of your competitors as the market becomes crowded
Your company is looking for new products to solve new problems as demand for your product dies down

title: Phases of growth

body:
Marketing is a way to keep your customers' needs at the heart of what you do, to find out what they want, and persuade them to buy your products. 


Your marketing plan should outline who you are trying to reach first, how you are better than competitors, and how you will persuade them with your messages. 


You should always have a clear idea of what you are trying to achieve with your marketing. This will change depending on the stage your business is at. 


Marketing should be approached as a series of experiments to find out what customers really respond to and want. Your plan should be continually tweaked.
title: How to plan your marketing. Let's wrap it up

body:
Now that you know what is going into your marketing plan, let's work out who your market is and how they currently shop. 


Let's look at:

  • Identifying the steps in the customer buying process
  • Knowing how to find out more from your customers about how they shop
  • Influencing your customers at each step of the buying process
title: Satisfying customers needs and desires

body:
Professor Phrabhu at University of Cambridge will explain each phase of the customer buying journey. 


He also shares some tips for following up on this model by speaking to real customers about how they really shop.
title: How do your customers search?

_media._source: C4M2 : Customer Buying Process - Research from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: This flow chart summarises the steps explained in Professor Prabhu's video.
title: Steps of the customer journey

displayTitle: How can you find customers to talk to?
body:
Nothing beats talking to customers!


Talking to customers can give you golden insights into how your customers shop, which should save you marketing money down the line. Here are some ideas for getting hold of customers.

_items.title: Blogs
_items.body: Contact bloggers or people featured on blogs who you think might be willing to speak to you
Use networks of family and friends to find potential customers willing to meet you for a coffee
_items.title: Networks

_items.body:
Go to meetups to meet the people who might want to buy your product.


By joining, you might be able to contribute to their community (sincerely!) and build networks of contacts who might be willing to speak to you and introduce you to other potential customers. 


Show me - meetup
_items.title: Meetups

_items.body:
Join networks of other entrepreneurs.


They might not be interested in your product but maybe their mum is or their sister or other contact of theirs would?
_items.title: Other founders

title: How can you find customers to talk to?

displayTitle: Influence your customers throughout their buying journey
body:
As a customer moves through the buying process, a business needs to find ways to influence them, using the 4Ps: product, price,  place (where they sell), and promotion (advertising and marketing).


This chart should help you plan the ways you can influence customers' buying decisions.
title: Influence your customers throughout their buying journey

body:
There are four phases to the customer buying journey.


Which is the odd one out?

_incorrect.final: Are you sure about that?

_feedback.correct: Well done! That's right, 'decline' is a phase in a market as it matures. It's not a phase in a customer's journey as they shop.

_items.text: Search
Evaluation
Decline
Purchase
Post-product

title: The customer buying journey

body:
There are four common methods to find out how your customers search for your product.


Which is the odd one out?

_items.text: Just guess! You have bought enough things in your life too
Look online for people in the public eye - bloggers, people interviewed for blogs - and ask them for a coffee.
Look online for people in the public eye - bloggers, people interviewed for blogs - and ask them for a coffee. You might be surprise how
Go to meetups (meetup.com) with potential customers and build networks
Join local entrepreneurs' networks and help each other out with introductions to potential customers

title: How do your customers search?

body: Which phases of the customer journey are illustrated in the examples below?

_items.text: An advert for travel insurance on public transport posters
A website with good visibility on Google that clearly explains what your company offers
A list of your clear unique selling points on your website
A competitive price
A free bike service within two weeks of buying a bike

title: Customer buying process

body:
Marketing aims to influence customers through their buying journey. 


Find out as much as possible about how your customers shop. Don't be shy about building networks and asking customers for a coffee and a chat. You might be pleasantly surprised how willing people are to help out. These insights will help you to hit the right note much faster.


Customers could be individuals or organisations. If they are organisations, find out which individuals are involved at each stage of the buying journey.
title: How your customers shop. Let's wrap it up

body:
How do your competitors behave, and how can you be better than them?


 Let's see how to:

  • Identify who your competitors are
  • Explain clearly how you are better than them
  • Decide what kind of relationship to have with your competitors
title: Fortune favours the bold!

body:
Professor Phrabhu at University of Cambridge explains that your competitors are not the only companies operating in your market.


He also explains how the type of competitors you face might change as your market moves through the four phases of introduction, growth,  maturity, and decline.


Competitor analysis needs to be an ongoing activity to stay vigilant to new threats.
title: Who are your competitors?

_media._source: C4M3 : Who are your competitors? Have you considered all angles? from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Here is a recap on Professor Phrabhu's  talk on the types of threats you could face.

_items.body:
In a new market, you might face competition from other product classes. 


For example, when Air BnB first launched, it was competing against hotels and serviced apartments.
_items.title: New markets
Growing markets
_items.body:
In a growing market, you might be competing against other brands in the same product class 


For example, there are now many online clothes stores competing for market share including Asos, BooHoo, Mr Porter and Netaporter.

In the maturity and decline phase, competition may be between competing technologies.


For example, PC computers competed on memory and processing speed, but effectively died out altogether as laptops and notebooks took over the market.
_items.title: Maturity and decline

title: What threats could you face?

body:
Doing better than than your competitors is called Sources of Strategic Advantage. 


Through your marketing, you should consider what benefits your strategic advantages allow you to pass on to your customers, which in turn make you better than your competitors.


Here are some potential sources of competitive advantage.

_items.title: Skills
_items.body: For example, TESLA might claim that by attracting the best engineers, it can offer electric cars that are faster and more efficient than others on the market.

For example, Sainsbury's might claim that their systems - including large networks of shops on busy high streets - make them the best place to buy day-to-day groceries, rather than, for example, smaller shops who cannot afford such busy locations.
_items.title: Systems

_items.body: For example, Coca-Cola might claim that they make the best tasting Cola because they have a secret recipe that is better than anyone else's.
_items.title: Resources - such as a patent or a brand

_items.body:
For example, Google might claim that they will always stay ahead of the competition because their company's culture revolves around listening to customers evolving needs and fostering innovation. 


This means they will always be the first to identify and solve customers' problems with innovative new products.
_items.title: Learning organisation

title: Stay ahead of your competitors

body:
Competition is not always a bad thing. 


For example, in new markets, it could prove that there is demand for a product like yours.


Sometimes, it will be to your advantage to take on your competitors head-to-head. 


For example, in a market such as soft drinks, where customers are likely to choose lower prices, it makes sense for competitors to try and offer cheaper prices than others.


In other cases, it is better to co-ordinate with competitors.


For example, rather than trying to invent a better version of Windows, why not focus on building an app which rides on their large customer base to offer them extra functionality?


In reality, most businesses use a combination of head-to-head competition and co-ordination at different times.
title: Your relationship with competitors

body: Match the examples of competition to the phase of a company's growth.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure? 


A service that offers medical consultations via Skype is in introduction phase. A supermarket launching a new banking service is in growth phase. A new phone that offers the same functionality as competitors with double their battery life, processing speed and storage capacity, is in maturity and decline.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure?


A service that offers medical consultations via Skype is in introduction phase. A supermarket launching a new banking service is in growth phase. A new phone that offers the same functionality as competitors with double their battery life, processing speed and storage capacity, is in maturity and decline.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


A service that offers medical consultations via Skype is in introduction phase. A supermarket launching a new banking service is in growth phase. A new phone that offers the same functionality as competitors with double their battery life, processing speed and storage capacity, is in maturity and decline.

_options.text: Competing against other product types : Introduction phase
Competing against other brands in an established product type : Growth
Competing against better technologies : Maturity and decline

_items.text: A service that offers medical consultations via Skype

_options.text: Competing against other product types : Introduction phase
Competing against other brands in an established product type : Growth
Competing against better technologies : Maturity and decline

_items.text: A supermarket launching a new banking service

_options.text: Competing against other product types : Introduction phase
Competing against other brands in an established product type : Growth
Competing against better technologies : Maturity and decline

_items.text: A new phone that offers the same functionality as competitors with double their battery life, processing speed and storage capacity.

title: Your competitors

body: Match the type of competitive advantage to the examples.

_items.text: A visionary leadership team with unique industry experience
A visionary leadership team with unique industry experience
Ten years of data about your customer base
A strong internal culture of innovation

title: How are you different?

body:
Relationships with competitors can be very helpful for you both.


Which two are not helpful?

_items.text: Head-to-head, confrontational competition at all times
Compete with them head-to-head on some fronts and co-ordinate with them on other points
Wherever you can co-ordinate with them to get a win-win outcome
Hide from them whenever you can

title: Your relationships with competitors

body:
Find out who your competitors are. 


Think 'outside the box' and keep monitoring the landscape as it changes. 


Work out your strategic competitive advantages - skills, systems, resources, or learning organisation.


Work out how that helps you give your customers a better offer. Communicate those advantages through marketing.


Think about how you can be a learning organisation from day 1 and build a culture of listening and innovation. 


Competition can be helpful to you. 


Consider ways to compete with competitors head-to head and on opportunities to cooperate.
title: Be better than your competitors. Let's wrap it up

body:
Now it is time for action.


Your marketing plan will cover:

  • Who your customers are and how they can be grouped by similar needs
  • Which groups you will target first
  • How your company offers a better proposition to customers than competitors
  • How you plan to communicate your messages to target customers
title: Segment and conquer!

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222517192" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
Professor Phrabhu at University of Cambridge talks about how marketing meets the evolving needs and wants of our customers. 


In theory, we should respond to the needs of each individual customer. This is often difficult or impractical in reality. 


Segmentation is the process of putting customers with similar needs into groups to develop solutions that solve their problems at the same time.
title: What is segmentation?

body: Professor Phrabhu at University of Cambridge describes how you might go about segmenting the market for a new type of beer.
title: Identify your market segments

_media._source: C4M4 : Segmenting Marketing - How do you research and define segments? from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Here's a summary of Professor Phrabhu's ways you can group customers who might have similar needs.
displayTitle: Recap: Four ways to define your market segments

_items.body:
Information on a census.


For example, age, gender, income.
_items.title: Demographics

_items.body: For example, risk taker or risk averse.
_items.title: Personality and lifestyle

_items.body: For example, someone who uses your product several times a day or once in a blue moon.
_items.title: Usage
Benefits seeking
_items.body: Customers looking for a specific benefit e.g.: a specific taste or a specific feeling.

title: Recap: Four ways to define your market segments

body:
Malcom Gladwell at The New Yorker magazine, explains how a visionary consultant segmented the tomato sauce market.


Skip to 5:30 if you don't have time.
displayTitle: Case study: Segmenting the spaghetti sauce market
title: Case study: Segmenting the spaghetti sauce market

displayTitle: Which segments should you target first?
body:
Now that you have grouped your customers into segments, how can you choose which ones to cater for?


Professor Phrabhu at University of Cambridge tells us how.
title: Which segments should you target first?

_media._source: C4M4 : Targeting from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: How many segments should you choose?
body: Here are three ways to think about how many segments to choose. There are trade-offs for each.

_items.body:
Mass marketing targets the largest possible number of segments - try to cater for everyone as far as possible.


For example, Tesco supermarkets.
_items.title: Mass marketing
Differentiated marketing
_items.body:
Differentiated marketing will try to offer variations to suit every taste.


For example, Diet Coke, Coke Zero, Coca Cola.

_items.title: Niche marketing
_items.body:
Niche marketing will strongly target a particular niche.


For example, Jaguar cars.

title: How many segments should you choose?

displayTitle: Which segment should you target first?
body: Here are some helpful questions to ask yourself when you try to decide which segments you should target first.

_items.body:
• Who are the groups you can best serve? 
  • Which are the largest groups?
  • Which groups will be able to generate the largest margins?
_items.title: Customers

_items.body:
• Which segments have less competition?
  • Which segments have competition that is not as good as us?
_items.title: Competitors

_items.body: • What's our marketing budget to take on large competitors in a specific segment?
_items.title: Company

title: Which segment should you target first?

body:
Now that you know which customers you are trying to target,  align your channels to convince them you are the best company to solve their problem. 


Professor Phrabhu at University of Cambridge tells us how.
title: Communicate your proposition to customers

_media._source: C4M4 : Marketing Plan - Positioning from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: Use the 4Ps to target customer segments

_items.title: Your product
_items.body: Offer exactly what your customers need and want
Make it affordable for customers while sending out the right signals about your brand
_items.title: Your price
Your place
_items.body: Choose to sell your product in shops, on websites or through partners that your customers like to use and which will send the right brand messages

_items.title: Your promotion
_items.body: Tell customers you will serve them better than your competitors using online and offline channels

title: Use the 4Ps to target customer segments

body:
A perceptual map is a good example of how to do this. 


Professor Prabhu talks us through the case study of a new type of car.
title: Mapping it all out

_media._source: C4M3 : Perceptual Map from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Which statement best explains why it is important to segment a market?

_items.text: If a company tries to be all things to all people there is a danger it could fail to serve ANY group of customers really well
Because it is too expensive to reach a whole market at once
Because if you reach out to all people, you might seem like a poor quality brand

title: Segment your market

body: Which two important questions does targeting address?

_items.text: How long should I target customer segments for?
Which customer segments should I target?
How many segments should I target?

title: Targeting

body: Which model best describes the channels your business has for reaching customers?

_items.text: The 3Cs of customer, company, and competition
The 4Ps of product, place, price, promotion

title: Channels for reaching customers

body: You have seen how to define groups of customers with similar needs, choose which ones to reach first, explain to them how you are better than your competition and explain all of this clearly in a perceptual map.
title: Write your marketing plan. Let's wrap it up

body:
Calculating your marketing costs is a core part of your business strategy. 


Let's see how to:

  • Calculate a marketing budget for your business 
  • Design marketing tests to find out as soon as possible if your marketing and product offer are on point
title: Getting value for money?

body:
Marketing is a core part of your business strategy. 


Here are the questions you need to resolve to work out how much to spend on marketing.

_items.title: How many units of my product do I need to sell to cover my costs and break even?
What proportion of people who land on my website end up purchasing?
How many people need to land on my website to make enough sales?
How much does it cost on average to get a customer to come to my site?
How much do I need to invest in a marketing strategy to make the sales that I need to be profitable?

title: What defines my marketing spend?

body:
The formula for working out how many units you need to sell to break even is simple. 


However, you'll need to know what your fixed costs and variable costs are first.

_items.body:
These are expenses you would incur regardless of how many products you made or sold.


For example, website hosting, salaries or office rent.


Fixed marketing costs might include the salary of a marketing manger or a subscription to a trade magazine to stay informed on industry trends.


Some of those fixed costs will be direct fixed costs. That means they can be directly attributed to a specific product or product range - like the salary of a person who oversees only women's footwear.


Other costs will be harder to track and they are indirect fixed costs like the cost of running your website or running your office.  They are not linked to a specific product or product range.
_items.title: Fixed costs

_items.body:
These are costs that change as you make more products. 


They includes things like the cost of product deliveries to customers or the cost of warehousing. 


For sales, this might include the commission you pay a salesperson or the cost of a particular promotion or campaign.


Within variable costs, you will have direct variable costs that can be directly traced to making and selling specific products or services. 


For example, the cost of a Facebook advertising campaign for your new collection.


The other costs will be indirect variable costs.


They cannot be traced to specific products or product ranges.


For example, electricity and water costs. This is rarely traceable back to individual products but goes up the more products you make.
_items.title: Variable costs

title: Calculate your costs

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

body: Once you have itemised all your fixed and variable costs, you can work out how many units you would need to sell to break even.
title: Calculate your break even point

body: Now you know how many units you need to sell to break even, you might be thinking about how you can keep costs to a minimum. Here are some ideas for reducing fixed costs.

_items.body:
For example, if you decide to expand your sales market from the UK to the whole of Europe (using the same factory, team, marketing) you will achieve economies of scale.


The fixed costs stay the same while the revenues increase.
_items.title: Reduce the cost of making each unit by targeting the mass market

_items.body:
For example, you could reduce manufacturing costs by outsourcing to a specialist company in a country where salaries are lower. 


Or you could reduce fixed, set-up costs by turning your business into a franchise. This is what many fast food stores do.
_items.title: Reduce fixed costs

_items.body:
Try to be quicker, better and cheaper at what you do. 


For example, if you have run similar marketing campaigns before, think about which images, data and staff can be re-used to get the same impact for less money.
_items.title: Reduce variable costs

title: Reduce your fixed costs

body:
A conversion rate is the percentage of customers coming to your website who end up buying a product. 


Once you start getting traffic to the website, you can measure this using Google analytics. But before your launch, you'll need to use industry averages or competitor analysis tools to make a realistic estimation. 


Using this estimated figure, you can calculate how many customers you need to bring to your site. 


Here is the conversion rate formula.


Minimum number of customer website hits to break-even = (Units needed to sell for break-even / Conversion Rate figure) x 100. 


For example, if I need to sell 200 pairs of shoes to break even, and conversion is 2%, I need 10,000 visitors to come to the website. 


To calculate the ratio for this example:


(200 shoes to break-even /2%) x 100 = 10,000 visitors
title: Calculate your conversion rate

body:
For some types of advertising, it will be simple to calculate these costs. 


For example, The Adwords keyword finder tool can tell you the estimated cost per click for the keywords you are targeting. You can take an average cost from there. 


For other streams of marketing, costs might be harder to pin down.


For example, you might know how much you are paying an SEO agency for their help but it's harder to predict how much organic traffic you'll generate and when. 


Ultimately, you should use as much data as possible derived from tools or industry benchmarks to estimate the cost of customer engagement. 


Once you know how many customer visits you need and what it will cost to get them to your site, you can work out your budget. 


For example, let's go back to our 200 shoes calculation.

  • Sell 200 pairs of shoes to break even
  • Industry standard conversion rate for online shoe retailers - 2% 
  • Average cost per click for keywords such as 'buy Nike Airs online' - 50 pence per click

Calculation:

((200 / 2 )*100) x 0.50 = 5,000
displayTitle: What will it cost to get customers to my website?
title: What will it cost to get customers to my website?

body:
The conjoint analysis technique requires some maths skills to calculate correctly, but it allows you to design tests that show you which features are most appealing to customers. 


For example, if you are thinking of marketing a mobile phone, this test would show you the winning combination of price, colour, the material or the name and how popular the different variations will be.


Professor Prabhu at University of Cambridge discusses some tests you can run on customers.
title: Testing what works: conjoint analysis

_media._source: C5M5 - Conjoint Analysis from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
C5M5 - AB Testing from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
This type of testing compares the attractiveness of two options to your customer group. 


For example, you could set up a test on your website which shows one group of customers the website with a photo of a man on it, and the other group of customers see a photo of a woman. You can analyse your website traffic to see which photo generated the most sales in the long term. 


This simple test generates useful insights about what makes customers tick.
title: Testing what works: AB testing

body: Are the following costs fixed or variable?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Fixed costs are costs that you would incur whether you sell 1 or 100 units.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Fixed costs are costs that you would incur whether you sell 1 or 100 units.

_items.text: The cost of hosting your website
Rent for your office
Salary for your chief operating officer
The cost of delivering each product by van
Cost of a Google adwords ad for a specific product

title: Fixed and variable costs

body: Which is the correct formula for calculating the number of units you need to break-even and start making a profit?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure that's right? 


Breakeven = fixed costs / (price per unit - variable cost per unit)

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Break-even = fixed costs / (price per unit - variable cost per unit)

_items.text: Fixed costs / (price per unit - variable cost per unit)
Fixed costs x (price per van - variable cost per unit)
Salaries / (price per unit - fixed cost per unit)

title: Calculate break-even

body: How dynamic should your marketing strategy be?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Your marketing strategy should by dynamic. All marketing activity should be approached as a test to find out more about what your customers want.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Your marketing strategy should be dynamic. All marketing activity should be approached as a test to find out more about what your customers want.

_items.text: Not very - you set it once and follow the course
Somewhat - it changes once a year when you review
Very - it changes all the time as you run tests on what customers prefer and work around their needs

title: Dynamic marketing strategy

body:
The amount you can spend on marketing depends on how many units you need to sell to break-even and also what you think is realistic. 


You can keep fixed and variable costs low by looking at options like outsourcing, economies of scale, and franchising. 


You can test the effectiveness of your marketing before ramping up your marketing by using, for example AB testing.
title: Make your marketing strategy work for you. Let's wrap it up
